chunks.original_text: 是以圣人去甚，去奢，去泰。 传：夫天下者，天下之天下，非圣人之天下也。 故尧不能以天下与舜，禹不能以天下与启，此乃天下与舜与启，故尧禹亦因而与之耳。 若天下不与，欲强取而为之，吾未见其有得之者，而况能执而有之者哉。 是何也？ 天下者，犹神明之大器，非人智力可取而为之。 苟非天下所与，强取为之，其功必败。 苟非天下乐推，强执有之，其身必失。 何者？ 夫物有行之在前，则有随之於后者矣； 有煦之为温，则有吹之以寒者矣； 有用壮为强，则有用力而挫之者矣； 有因栽而培，则有因阙而堕之者矣。 是故有强取而为之，则有强夺而有之者矣。 是以圣人知天下不可以智力取，故以无事取天下，道成德着，而天下与之，是以天下乐推而不厌。 圣人无为而致治，故去甚者不强取也，去奢者不执有也，去泰者不辞让也。 《易》曰：亢龙有悔。 亢之为言也，知进而不知退，知存而不知亡，知得而不知丧。 其唯圣人乎，知进退存亡，而不失其正者，其唯圣人乎，亦其指也。 经：以道佐人主者，不以兵强天下，其事好还。 师之所处，荆棘生焉。 大军之后，必有凶年。 故善者果而已，不敢以取强。 果而勿矜，果而勿伐，果而勿憍，果而不得已，是果而勿强。 物壮则老，是谓不道，不道早已。 传：夫以道辅人主者，当以德服人心，不以甲兵之力取强於天下。 何者？ 取强於人，人必恶之。 天下之人恶之，则天下之兵加之矣。 故我取强於人，人亦取胜於我。 出乎己者，反乎己，是以其事好还复焉。 凡师旅所居，农耕必废，则荆棘生於田亩，杼轴空於都鄙，重以杀害生民，感伤和炁，则必水旱荐臻，凶荒仍岁矣。 人事既如彼，天意又如此，然则兵可去乎？ 曰：天生五材，废一不可，谁能去兵。 兵不可去，用之有道，故古之善用兵者，果而已矣，不以取强。 何谓果哉？ 勿矜其能，勿伐其功，勿憍其心。 虽果於三者，须不得已而后用，复果於济虽而不止，犹不敢以取强焉，则是果而勿强矣。 夫矜其能则好战，好战则不能安民； 伐其功则易争，易争则不能和众； 憍其心则生事，生事则不能阜财。 三果不存，七德尽废，好胜弗已，怙力取强，亡之道也。 於乎物壮必老，兵强必败，自然之势，可不戒哉。 且道以弱为用，而兵以强取胜，斯不合於道也，明矣。 不远而复，故无祗悔； 不道早已，则无大败。 《易》曰：迷复凶，有灾眚。 用行师，终有大败。 以其国君凶，至於十年不克征，不知早已之谓也。 经：夫佳兵者，不祥之器，物或恶之，故有道者不处。 君子居则贵左，用兵则贵右。 兵者不祥之器，非君子之器，不得已而用之，恬淡为上。 胜而不美，而美之者，是乐杀人。 夫乐杀人者，不可得志於天下。 吉事尚左，凶事尚右。 偏将军处左，上将军处右，言以丧礼处之。 杀人众多，以悲哀泣之，战胜则以丧礼处之。 传：夫佳尚兵谋之人，非祥善之材器，凡物犹或恶其意，有道者岂可安其事哉。 何者？ 天地之道，左阳而右阴，阳主德主生，阴主刑主杀。 故君子平居，则以有德者居左，斯贵左也。 即戎则以有勇者为右，斯贵右也。 君子以好生为德，武人以多杀为功，故知兵者是不祥之器用，非君子之器用也。
chunks.translated_text:
Thus, the Sage removes excess, removes extravagance, removes excessiveness.

**Scripture:**
The world is the world of the world, not the Sage’s alone.
Therefore, Yao could not give the world to Shun by force, nor could Yu give it to Qi by force—
it was the world that gave itself to Shun and Qi.
Thus, Yao and Yu merely followed its will.

If the world does not give itself, and one seeks to seize it by force,
I have never seen one who could take it,
let alone hold it.

Why is this?
The world is like a divine vessel of great clarity—
not something one can seize by intelligence or strength.
If one seizes it by force though it does not give itself,
the endeavor will surely fail.
If one grasps it though the world does not willingly yield,
one’s own person will surely perish.

For when things advance before,
there will be those who follow after;
when warmth is given,
there will be cold to follow;
when strength is used to dominate,
there will be force to counter it;
when one plants and nurtures,
there will be those who uproot and destroy.

Thus, if one seizes by force,
others will seize it back by force.
Therefore, the Sage knows the world cannot be taken by intelligence or strength,
and so takes it by doing nothing.
When the Dao is complete and virtue established,
the world gives itself willingly,
and thus the world gladly follows without tiring.

The Sage governs by non-action,
and so removes excess by not seizing by force,
removes extravagance by not grasping possession,
removes excessiveness by not refusing to yield.

The *Classic of Changes* says:
*"The overbearing dragon regrets it."*
The meaning of *overbearing*—
knowing how to advance but not how to retreat,
knowing how to preserve but not how to perish,
knowing how to gain but not how to lose—
only the Sage knows how to advance and retreat,
preserve and perish,
without losing the proper way.
Only the Sage understands this—
this is its meaning.

**Scripture:**
Those who assist the sovereign with the Dao
do not use force to compel the world,
for their deeds return to them.
Where the army encamps,
thorns and brambles grow.
After great armies pass,
there will surely be years of famine.

Thus, the virtuous act decisively but do not seize by force.
Act decisively but do not boast,
act decisively but do not vaunt,
act decisively but do not be arrogant—
though decisive, they do not act by force.
When things are strong, they grow old—
this is called *not the Dao*,
and *not the Dao* brings early ruin.

**Scripture:**
Those who assist the sovereign with the Dao
must win hearts with virtue,
not use arms to compel the world.
For if one seizes strength from others,
others will hate it.
If the world’s people hate it,
the world’s armies will rise against it.
Thus, if I seize strength from others,
others will seize victory from me.
What is done to oneself returns to oneself—
thus, their deeds return to them.

Where armies dwell,
farming is neglected,
and thorns grow in the fields.
Looms stand idle in the villages,
and the people are burdened with slaughter,
disturbing the harmonious *qi*—
then drought and flood will surely follow,
and years of famine will ensue.

Human affairs are as they are,
and Heaven’s will is as it is—
then can war be avoided?
It is said:
Heaven produces the five elements;
to neglect one is impossible—
who can abolish war?

War cannot be abolished,
but its use must follow the Dao.
Thus, the ancients who skillfully used war
acted decisively but did not seize by force.

What is meant by *decisive*?
Do not boast in one’s abilities,
do not vaunt one’s achievements,
do not be arrogant in one’s heart.
Though decisive in these three things,
one must still act only when unavoidable,
and though decisive in achieving victory,
one must still not dare to seize by force—
this is *decisive yet not forceful*.

To boast in one’s abilities is to love war;
to love war is to be unable to settle the people.
To vaunt one’s achievements is to invite contention;
to invite contention is to be unable to harmonize the masses.
To be arrogant is to provoke strife;
to provoke strife is to be unable to enrich the realm.

If these three *decisive* virtues are lost,
the seven virtues are all abandoned,
and the love of victory knows no end—
relying on strength to seize by force,
this is the path to ruin.

Ah! When things are strong, they grow old;
when armies are strong, they meet defeat—
this is the natural order,
and one must take heed.

Moreover, the Dao uses weakness for effectiveness,
while war uses strength to win—
this clearly does not align with the Dao.
If one does not retreat in time, regret will come;
if one does not abandon the Dao early, great defeat will follow.

The *Classic of Changes* says:
*"Lost and returning—disaster.
There will be calamity and misfortune.
Using armies—surely there will be great defeat.
The sovereign’s misfortune will last ten years without victory—
this is what is meant by not abandoning early."*

**Scripture:**
Fine weapons are ominous instruments—
things often hate them,
and so those who follow the Dao do not dwell upon them.

The gentleman, at home, values the left;
in war, values the right.
War is an ominous instrument,
not the instrument of the gentleman—
it is used only when unavoidable,
and calmness is supreme.

To win yet not rejoice in victory,
but to rejoice is to delight in killing.
Those who delight in killing
cannot achieve their desires in the world.

Auspicious matters favor the left,
ominous matters favor the right.
The left general is placed on the left,
the right general on the right—
this is to treat war as a funeral rite.
When many are killed,
one should weep in sorrow,
and victory should be treated as a funeral rite.

**Scripture:**
Those who excel in military strategy
are not auspicious or virtuous materials.
Even ordinary things may hate their intent—
how could those who follow the Dao comfortably engage in such matters?

For the Dao of Heaven and Earth:
the left is yang, the right is yin.
Yang governs virtue and life,
yin governs punishment and death.
Thus, in peace, the gentleman places the virtuous on the left—
this is why the left is honored.
In war, the brave are placed on the right—
this is why the right is honored.

The gentleman values life as virtue,
while warriors value killing as achievement—
thus, those who know war are wielding ominous instruments,
not the instruments of the gentleman.

chunks.original_text: 若夫蛮夷猾夏，寇贼奸宄，则不得已而用之，然未尝为起戎之首，故曰不敢为主而为客，不敢进寸而退尺。 以恬於见利，淡於欲胜为上，不以敢於勇进，嗜於多杀为贵。 善在不战而屈人，不以战胜而为美，何也？ 凡战以多杀人为胜，美之者是乐杀人。 乐杀人者，人亦将乐杀之，岂唯人将杀之，天亦将杀之。 何哉？ 生者天地之大德也，乐杀人者逆天德。 若使乐杀人者得志於天下，则天下之人几尽矣。 天必不助，而况於人乎。 且吉事则拱而尚左，凶事则拱而尚右。 偏将军者，兵之佐，故居於左。 上将军者，兵之主，故居於右。 所以居於右者，居其上势也，居上势者尚於右，是以丧礼处之也。 夫战而胜者，杀人多也，杀人多者叉以悲哀泣之，是战而胜者，则以丧礼处之也。 前言不祥之器，后言丧礼处之，皆再叹其辞，恶杀人之甚也。 经：道常无名，朴虽小，天下不敢臣。 侯王若能守，万物将自宾。 天地相合，以降甘露，人莫之令而自均。 传：道之所以能常者，无名之体也。 夫无名之体亦谓之无名之朴，其体甚微眇，其道甚尊大，故为天地之始，而天下莫之敢臣也。 侯王能守此无名之朴，则万物莫不宾服。 故山高则牂羊至矣，水深则蛟龙至矣。 山之不高，水之不深，神物且犹不至，而况於众物哉。 夫天地中和之气合，则膏露降於万物，万物均被其泽，莫有使之而然。 侯王能法天地之中和，以守冲用之道，则德泽普於天下，天下莫知所以然，所谓侯王若能守，万物将自宾也。 经：始制有名，名亦既有，夫亦将知止，知止所以不殆。 譬道之在天下，犹川谷之与江海。 传：所谓始者，即无名也。 夫唯无名之体，故能制有名之用，亦既有名，名将游矣。 故亦将知止，止其所也，游止其所，名止其实，事止其理。 知止而止，故不至危殆。 然则所谓名止其实，亦实其名也，故循名而督实，按实而定名。 名实相当则国治，名实不当则国乱。 名生於实，实生於名，名实相生，反相为情，故有道之君操契以责名。 名者，天下之网，圣人之符。 张天下之网，用圣人之符，则万物之情无所逃矣。 故审其名以复其实，考其实以正其名，则是非之见若白黑。 故判为两，合为一，是非随名实，赏罚随是非。 是以见其象，致其形，循其理，正其名，故曰名自命，则事自定也。 因名命之，随事正之。 故尧之治天下也，以名，其名正而天下治； 桀之治天下也，亦以名，其名倚而天下乱。 故名者，圣人之所重也。 仲尼曰：必也，正名乎。 名不正，则人主忧劳； 人主忧劳，则官职烦乱。 白之顾益黑，求之而愈不得。 名正则人主无忧劳，无忧劳则不役其耳目之主，而百度惟贞，因形而任，不制於物，无为而治，清静以公，神通乎六合，意观乎无穷，所谓知止不殆也。 夫江海者，川谷之所归； 无名者，有名之所止。 譬诸天下之事，其归於道如此。 经：知人者智，自知者明。 胜人者有力，自胜者强。 知足者富，强行者有志。 不失其所者久，死而不亡者寿。 传：知出於外谓之智，如日火之外光。 知反於内谓之明，如金水之内景。 用弱以胜人之暴，为有道之力； 守柔以自胜其躁，为有德之强。 知足於利欲者，不亡其大业，故谓之富。 强行於仁义者，可至於盛德，故谓之有志。

「If one encounters the barbarous and the alien, the cunning and the treacherous, the marauders and the deceitful—
then one must reluctantly employ them,
yet never be the first to initiate conflict.
Thus it is said:
*"One does not dare to be the aggressor but the defender,
nor to advance an inch while retreating a foot."*

To remain tranquil in the face of gain,
and indifferent to the desire for victory—
this is the highest virtue.
To dare boldly to advance through valor,
and to delight in slaughter—
this is not the noble pursuit.

The true art lies in bending others without battle,
not in glorifying conquest through war—
why so?

For all wars are won by the multitude of slain—
those who praise such victory are those who take pleasure in killing.
Those who take pleasure in killing,
others will also take pleasure in killing them—
not only will others kill them,
but Heaven itself will punish them.
Why so?

Life is the greatest virtue of Heaven and Earth—
those who take pleasure in killing defy Heaven’s virtue.
If such men were to prevail in the world,
then nearly all people would perish.

Heaven will not aid them,
and what of men?

Moreover, in auspicious rites, one bows and honors the left,
while in inauspicious rites, one bows and honors the right.
The subordinate general, an aide to the military,
thus resides on the left.
The supreme general, the master of the military,
thus resides on the right.
This is why he resides on the right—
he holds the higher position of command.
Those who occupy the higher position are honored on the right,
and thus victory is treated as a funeral rite.

The conqueror in battle is he who slays many—
yet he should weep in sorrow for the slain,
for victory is treated as a funeral rite.
The earlier words spoke of an inauspicious instrument,
and now it is said that victory is treated as a funeral rite—
both are repeated laments,
for the cruelty of killing is deeply abhorred.

**Scripture:**
The Dao is always nameless,
yet the Uncarved (朴) is small—
though small, the world dare not enslave it.
If lords and kings could guard it,
all things would come willingly.

When Heaven and Earth combine,
sweet dew descends—
no one commands it,
yet it is evenly distributed.

**Explication:**
The Dao endures because of its nameless essence.
This nameless essence is also called the nameless Uncarved (朴),
whose form is exceedingly subtle and minute,
yet whose Dao is supremely noble and vast—
thus it becomes the origin of Heaven and Earth,
and the world dare not enslave it.
If lords and kings could guard this nameless Uncarved (朴),
then all things would submit in service.

Thus, when mountains are high, the wild rams come,
and when waters are deep, the dragon spirits arrive.
If mountains were not high,
or waters not deep,
even divine creatures would not come—
how much more so for ordinary things?

When the central harmonious *qi* of Heaven and Earth combines,
then nourishing dew descends upon all things,
and all things are evenly blessed by its grace—
none can command it to be so.

If lords and kings could emulate the central harmony of Heaven and Earth,
and uphold the Dao of the Uncarved and its application,
then their virtue would spread universally throughout the world,
and the world would not know how it came to be—
this is what is meant by:
*"If lords and kings could guard it,
all things would come willingly."*

**Scripture:**
When naming first began,
once names were established,
one would also know when to stop—
to know when to stop is to avoid peril.

The Dao in the world is like rivers and valleys to the great seas.

**Explication:**
By "beginning," it refers to the nameless.
Only the nameless essence can govern the use of names—
once names are established,
they will wander without restraint.
Thus one must also know when to stop,
to halt at the proper place—
names halt at their proper place,
affairs halt at their proper principles.
To know when to stop and do so,
is to avoid danger and peril.

Then, what is meant by "names halt at their proper place"?
It means to fulfill the names—
thus one follows names to supervise their fulfillment,
and examines fulfillment to rectify the names.
When names and fulfillment correspond,
the state is well-ordered;
when they do not correspond,
the state is chaotic.
Names arise from fulfillment,
fulfillment arises from names—
names and fulfillment give rise to each other,
yet they also oppose each other—
thus the sagely ruler uses the *契* (契) to hold names accountable.

Names are the world’s net,
the sage’s talisman.
To cast the world’s net,
and wield the sage’s talisman,
then the emotions of all things have no place to escape.

Thus, to scrutinize names and restore their fulfillment,
and to examine fulfillment and correct the names,
then right and wrong become as clear as white and black.
Thus, to separate them is to make them two,
to unite them is to make them one—
right and wrong follow names and fulfillment,
rewards and punishments follow right and wrong.
Thus, to perceive their forms,
to achieve their shapes,
to follow their principles,
to correct their names—
this is why it is said:
*"Names are self-appointed,
then affairs are self-determined."*

One follows names to appoint them,
and examines affairs to rectify them.
Thus, when Yao governed the world,
he used names—
his names were correct,
and the world was well-ordered.
When Jie governed the world,
he also used names—
his names were perverse,
and the world was chaotic.
Thus, names are what the sage holds most dear.

Master Zhongni said:
*"It must be so—
one must correct the names!"*
If names are not corrected,
then the ruler will be burdened with cares and labors;
if the ruler is burdened with cares and labors,
then the offices and duties will be disorderly.
The more one seeks the black,
the more one finds the white—
yet the more one seeks it,
the more one fails to obtain it.
If names are corrected,
then the ruler will have no cares or labors;
without cares or labors,
he will not tax the ears and eyes of his people—
and all undertakings will be steadfast.
He will follow forms to assign roles,
not be constrained by things,
and govern without action—
clearly and impartially,
his spirit will permeate the six directions,
his intent will survey the boundless—
this is what is meant by:
*"To know when to stop is to avoid peril."*

The great seas are where rivers and valleys converge,
and the nameless is where all names cease.
Thus, all undertakings of the world
return to the Dao in this manner.

**Scripture:**
He who knows others is wise,
he who knows himself is enlightened.
He who conquers others has strength,
he who conquers himself is powerful.
He who knows contentment is rich,
he who perseveres in action has resolve.
He who does not lose his place endures,
he who dies yet does not perish attains longevity.

**Explication:**
Knowledge that comes from without is called wisdom—
like the external radiance of the sun and fire.
Knowledge that reflects inward is called enlightenment—
like the internal reflection of metal and water.

To use gentleness to overcome others’ violence
is the strength of one who follows the Dao;
to uphold softness and conquer one’s own agitation
is the power of one who possesses virtue.

He who knows contentment in worldly gains and desires
does not lose his great undertaking—
thus he is called rich.
He who perseveres in benevolence and righteousness
can attain great virtue—
thus he is called one of resolve.

He who does not lose his place endures,
he who dies yet does not perish attains longevity.»

Yang governs virtue and life,

chunks.original_text: 动而不失其所怛，故可久身，死而道不亡，故为寿。 经：大道泛兮，其可左右。 万物恃之以生而不辞，功成而不居有，爱养万物而不为主。 常无欲，可名於小，万物归之不为主，可名於大。 是以圣人终不为大，故能成其大。 传：大道之用，其犹鬼神之德乎。 泛泛乎可在乎左，可在乎右。 洋洋乎若在乎上，若在其前后#2。 为万物之母，故恃之以生。 与天地合德，故其功易成。 以其亲之至，故不谢厥德。 以其大之极，故不称有功。 慈育万类，长而不宰，故常无欲以观其妙，则可以名其朴为小。 万物归之不为其尊主，若川谷之与江海，则可以名其道为大。 夫川谷之赴江海，受之而不厌，是未尝自尊。 天下皆归圣人，圣人容之而不倦，是终不为大。 圣人守无名之小朴，终不自以为大，所以为万物之所宾，卒能成其大。 经：执大象，天下往，往而不害，安平泰。 乐与饵，过客止。 道之出口，淡乎其无味。 视之不足见，听之不足闻，用之不可既。 传：大象者，道也。 夫能执古之道以御今之有，则天下万物皆归而往之矣。 夫圣人视民如赤子，唯恐其伤，而况有事伤之乎？ 未尝有以伤之，则归而往之者，莫有受其伤矣。 莫受其伤，则天下皆安其夷泰矣。 夫乐可以悦耳，饵可以适口，则旅人为之留连，行客为之欢餍，虽即时有感，然非其所安，不可久处。 故《易》曰：鸟焚其巢，旅人先笑，后号咷也。 夫执大象者则不然，不以欲乐示於人，故言之出口淡乎其无味，教之入心泊乎其不美。 希乎夷乎虽不足以听视，然用之不穷，酌之不竭，弥乎千万年而不可以既。 经：将欲歙之，必固张之； 将欲弱之，必固强之； 将欲废之，必固兴之； 将欲夺之，必固与之。 是谓微明。 柔弱胜刚强，鱼不可脱於渊，国之利器，不可以示人。 传：夫圣人之渊奥莫妙於权实，实以顺常为体，权以反经为用，权所以济实，实所以行权，权实虽殊，其归一揆。 老氏既以实导人，立知常之教； 又以权济物，明若反之言。 《易》所谓曲成万物而不遗，范围天地而不过者也。 夫欲除强梁，覆昏暴者，必因其利欲之心，以行歙张之术。 术之用曰：彼利欲之心方盛，必且足之令张，喜其足则获其情，然可歙之以正。 在《易□明夷》六四：入于左腹，获明夷之心，不出门庭是也。 夫足之令足所以极其张也，张则侈心愈益，故为众之所歙也。 此术甚微而明，圣人所以密用也。 至於将弱其志炁者，必且强其嗜欲，甚爱则大费，欲极则志衰。 小用之於身心，大用之於天下。 废兴与夺覆却相资，斯自然之理，以反为合者也。 经曰：反者道之动，弱者道之用。 能以柔弱制刚强，是用而反者也，用而反者实能制权也。 《易》曰：巽以行权。 又曰：巽称而稳。 夫巽之为象，风也。 风能应四时，挠万物，而万物莫见其形。 权能乘天机，适世变，而人莫知其用。 夫巽之为义，顺也。 巽顺可以行权，权行则能制物，故柔弱可以制刚强，则义甚彰而用甚隐矣。 何以明之？ 昔者文王二天下之三，而犹诎伏殷纣，乃献漆沮之地，请去炮烙之刑。 夫纣之贪心方炽，故文王请献之地，是足之令张也，纣既得地而喜，故文王请去其刑，是歙之以正，此文王之权也。 昔武王观兵盟津，曰纣之恶未极，於是还师二年，然后兴牧野之役。

---

**Explication:**
The Dao moves without losing its place—
thus the body may endure long.
Death comes, yet the Way does not perish—
thus it is called longevity.

**Explication:**
The Great Dao flows unrestrained,
yet it may be found on either side.
All things depend upon it for life,
yet it does not decline to bestow.
It fulfills its function yet does not dwell upon it,
nurturing all things yet claiming no mastery.

Ever without desire, it may be called *small*—
yet when all things return to it without making it their lord,
it may be called *great*.

Therefore, the Sage never claims to be great,
and thus he achieves his greatness.

**Explication:**
The application of the Great Dao,
is it not like the virtue of ghosts and spirits?
It flows freely, found on left or right.
It drifts boundlessly, as if above or before and behind.

As the mother of all things, it is relied upon for life.
In harmony with Heaven and Earth in virtue, its work is easily accomplished.
Because its intimacy is supreme, it never denies its virtue.
Because its magnitude is absolute, it never claims its deeds.

It cherishes all creatures, fostering them without slaughter,
thus ever without desire, observing its marvel—
then its simplicity may be named *small*.
All things return to it without making it their sovereign lord,
like streams and valleys yielding to rivers and seas—
then its Dao may be named *great*.

When streams and valleys flow into the rivers and seas,
they receive without satiety—
this is because they never exalt themselves.
When all under Heaven return to the Sage,
he accepts them without weariness—
this is because he never claims to be great.

The Sage upholds the humble simplicity of the *small* (undifferentiated),
yet never considers himself great—
thus he becomes the guest of all things,
and ultimately achieves his greatness.

**Explication:**
Hold the Great Image, and all under Heaven will follow.
Follow yet cause no harm—
then peace and tranquility prevail.

Joy and bait,
yet travelers pass on without lingering.
The Way, when spoken of, is bland without flavor.
To gaze upon it is insufficient to see,
to listen to it is insufficient to hear—
yet its use is never exhausted.

**Explication:**
The Great Image is the Way.
He who can grasp the ancient Way to govern the present,
all things under Heaven will return and follow.

The Sage views the people as tender children,
fearing to harm them—
how much more would he avoid harming them in times of crisis?
If he never harms them, then those who return and follow
will suffer no injury from him.

If none suffer injury, then all under Heaven will dwell in ease and tranquility.
Joy can delight the ear,
bait can satisfy the palate—
then wayfarers will linger, travelers will revel,
though they may feel pleasure in the moment,
yet it is not their true resting place,
and they cannot remain long.

Thus the *Classic of Changes* says:
*"The bird burns its nest,
the wayfarer laughs first, then weeps bitterly."*

He who upholds the Great Image is not thus.
He does not display desire for pleasure to the people,
so when his words leave his mouth, they are bland without flavor;
when his teachings enter the heart, they are serene without adornment.
Though faint and subtle, they are not sufficient for sight or hearing,
yet their use is inexhaustible,
their measure never depleted—
spanning myriad ages without end.

**Explication:**
He who would gather must first disperse;
he who would weaken must first strengthen;
he who would discard must first promote;
he who would take away must first give.
This is called *subtle enlightenment*.

Softness overcomes hardness—
fish cannot escape the depths,
the sharpest tools of state
should not be displayed to the people.

**Explication:**
The Sage’s profound depths are most wondrous in *power and expedience* (权实).
*Expedience* (权) takes *harmony with nature* (顺常) as its essence,
*power* (实) employs *contrary measures* (反经) as its function.
*Expedience* aids *power*,
*power* implements *expedience*—
though they differ in name,
their purpose converges in unity.

The Master Lao first guided with *power*,
establishing the teaching of *constant knowledge*;
then he employed *expedience* to aid the people,
illustrating the principle of *contrary action*.

This is what the *Classic of Changes* speaks of:
*"The bending completes all things without loss,
the encompassing contains Heaven and Earth without excess."*

To remove the strong and violent,
to overturn the obscurantist and cruel—
one must rely upon their hearts of gain and desire,
and employ the arts of *gathering and dispersing*.

The use of these arts is thus:
When their hearts of gain and desire are at their peak,
one must indulge them to the fullest, letting them expand.
They delight in indulgence, and their true nature is revealed—
then one may gather them to bring them to order.

As in the *Classic of Changes*’ **"#2" (明夷)**—
the fourth hexagram:
*"Entering the left flank, capturing the heart of the obscurantist,
not stepping outside the gate."*

When indulgence is indulged to its utmost,
the heart of excess grows ever greater—
thus it is gathered by all.

This art is subtle yet clear,
the Sage’s hidden means of action.

As for weakening their resolve and *qi*,
one must first strengthen their cravings and desires.
Great love brings great expenditure,
desire pushed to its limit weakens the resolve.

Small use is upon the body and heart,
great use is upon all under Heaven.
Discarding and promoting, taking and giving,
mutually reinforce each other—
this is the natural principle,
where *contrary* becomes *harmonious*.

**Explication:**
The Way’s motion is *contrary*;
the Way’s function is *weakening*.
To govern with softness and weakness,
overcoming hardness and strength—
this is the *contrary* in use,
and the *contrary* in use truly governs *expedience*.

The *Classic of Changes* says:
*"The *submissive* (巽) moves to apply *expedience*."*
And again:
*"The *submissive* is steady when it conforms."*

The *submissive* (巽) as an image is the wind.
Wind responds to the four seasons,
bending all things—
yet no one sees its form.

*Expedience* rides the natural course of Heaven,
adapts to the changes of the world—
yet no one knows its use.

The meaning of *submissive* (巽) is *yielding*.
Yielding and submission can apply *expedience*,
and when *expedience* is applied,
it can govern the world—
thus softness and weakness can overcome hardness and strength,
and the meaning is most evident while the function is most hidden.

How can this be made clear?
In ancient times, King Wen ruled one-third of all under Heaven,
yet he still bowed and submitted to the tyrant Zhou (纣).
He offered the lands of *Lacquer* (漆) and *Stagnant* (沮),
and requested the abolition of the *Branding* (炮烙) punishment.

When Zhou’s greedy heart burned fiercely,
King Wen offered the lands—
this was indulging them to let them expand.
Zhou, once he gained the lands, rejoiced—
thus King Wen requested the removal of his punishment,
this was gathering them to bring them to order—
this was King Wen’s *expedience*.

In ancient times, King Wu surveyed his troops at the *Ming River Crossing* (盟津),
saying, *"The evil of Zhou has not yet reached its peak."*
Thus he returned his army for two years,
before raising the *Mao Field* (牧野) campaign.

chunks.original_text: 夫还於盟津，是足其张令极也，兴於牧野，是致其众之所歙，此武王之权也。 昔文王以文柔之道，虽念殷人不胜其酷，需尽去纣而后受之，此文王之实也。 昔武王以刚武之德，遽痛殷人之不胜其虐，遂亟诛纣而后取之，此武王之实也。 伯夷叔齐辅文王之实，正武王之权，谓以臣伐君不可以训，将以整三纲於后世，故相率而弃武王，饿死於首阳。 太公相武王之权，反文王之实，谓诛独夫纣，天下乃定，将以拯兆民於当代，故鹰扬而从武王，肆伐于大商。 周公召公成文武之业，将欲密救乱之权，显治安之实，於是休牛放马，倒载干戈，问《洪范》於箕子，迁顽民於洛邑，制礼作乐，偃武修文，流二南之化，致八百之祚，此又以权反实之大者也。 《易》曰：一阖一辟谓之变，往来不穷谓之通。 此皆微明之旨，以权实相济者也。 於乎圣人行权所以合乎道，小人窃权所以济乎奸。 鱼脱於渊则不可行，权离於实则不可用。 夫权之为物，国家之利器也，必深藏之，密用之，不可显示於人，惧其窃以为乱也。 故孔子曰：可与适道，未可与立。 可与立，未可与权。 在《易□乾》之九四曰：或跃在渊，无咎。 子曰：上下无常，非为邪也。 进退无恒，非离群也。 君子进德修业，欲及时也，故无咎。 《坤》之六四曰：括囊，无咎无誉。 子曰：天地变化，草木蕃； 天地闭，贤人隐。 括囊无咎，盖言谨也，慎不害也。 然则权之为用，圣人所难且慎也，可不谨乎，可不谨乎。 经：道常无为而无不为，侯王若能守，万物将自化。 化而欲作，吾将镇之以无名之朴。 无名之朴，亦将不欲。 不欲以静，天下将自正。 传：道之所以为常者，以其体无名，故无为，用有名，故无不为。 侯王能守此始与母之术，则万物之理得，而天下之事正，所谓我无为而民自化也。 德化既淳，天下清静，苟利欲之情将有萌兆，吾必以此大道之质奠而正之，使无得动矣。 夫上德无为而无以为，则同於道矣。 下德为之而有以为，则同於德矣。 得於德者，必失於道，故有无为之心者，必有无为之迹。 后世将寻其迹而忘其本，故为无为而至有为，故云无名之朴，亦将不欲者，将使心迹兼忘，则至於玄之又玄矣。 夫能心迹兼忘，事理玄会，则天下各正其性命，而无累於物之迹焉。 首篇以常道为体，常名为用，而极之於重玄。 此篇以无为为体，无不为为用，而统之以兼忘。 始末相贯，而尽其体用也。 道德真经传卷之二竟 #1亦将不欲：原本此句后衍『於不欲』三字，据指海本删。 #2若在其前后：疑作『若在乎下』。 道德真经传卷之三 吴郡陆希声传

「Thus, King Wu’s return to the Ming River Crossing was to fully indulge the tyrant’s arrogance, while his campaign at the Mao Field was to gather the people’s resentment to its extreme—this was King Wu’s *expedience*.

In ancient times, King Wen, through the Dao of gentle softness, though aware that the Yin people could not endure Zhou’s cruelty, still wished to completely remove Zhou before accepting them—this was King Wen’s *substance*.

King Wu, through the virtue/power of resolute strength, swiftly recognized that the Yin people could not bear Zhou’s tyranny, and thus hastened to slay Zhou before claiming their lands—this was King Wu’s *substance*.

The brothers Bo Yi (伯夷) and Shu Qi (叔齐) upheld King Wen’s *substance* and corrected King Wu’s *expedience*, declaring that a subject should not overthrow a sovereign as a precedent. They sought to establish the Three Bonds (三纲) for future generations, thus they collectively abandoned King Wu and starved to death at Shouyang (首阳).

The Duke of Zhou (太公) aided King Wu’s *expedience* and inverted King Wen’s *substance*, asserting that slaying the tyrannical Zhou would bring peace to the realm. He aimed to rescue the myriad people in the present age, thus he soared like an eagle and followed King Wu, unleashing devastation upon the Great Shang (大商).

The Duke of Zhou (周公) and the Duke of Shao (召公) completed the deeds of Wen and Wu, intending to secretly preserve the *expedience* of rectifying chaos while openly promoting the *substance* of governance and peace. Thus, they rested the oxen and released the horses, overturned the chariots and laid down the weapons, inquired about the *Great Response* (洪范) from Ji Zi (箕子), relocated the stubborn people to Luoyi (洛邑), established rituals and composed music, laid down arms and cultivated culture, spreading the influence of the Two Southern Schools (二南) and securing the eight-hundred-year prosperity of the Zhou (八百之祚). This was another instance of using *expedience* to invert *substance* on the grandest scale.

The *Classic of Changes* (《易》) states:
*"The opening and closing of one gate is called change (变),*
*and the ceaseless movement between extremes is called harmony (通)."*

These are subtle teachings,
whereby *expedience* and *substance* complement each other.

Ah! The Sage’s use of *expedience* aligns with the Dao,
while the petty man’s misuse of *expedience* serves his deceit.
A fish that escapes the deep pool cannot swim,
*Expedience* that departs from *substance* cannot be applied.

For *expedience* is a sharp instrument of statecraft—
it must be deeply concealed,
secretly employed,
and never openly displayed,
lest men seize it to incite disorder.

Thus Confucius said:
*"One may be capable of following the Dao,*
*but not yet of establishing it.*
*One may be capable of establishing it,*
*but not yet of wielding *expedience*.*"

In the *Hexagram of Qian* (□乾) at line four:
*"One leaps into the deep pool—*
*no blame."*

The Master said:
*"There is no fixed hierarchy of high and low,*
*this is not perverse (邪).*
*There is no constant forward or retreat,*
*this is not abandonment of the group (离群).*
*The Noble One advances in virtue/power and cultivates his undertakings,*
*seeking to fulfill his potential in due time—*
*thus there is no blame."*

In the *Hexagram of Kun* (《坤》) at line four:
*"Gather the sack—*
*no blame, no praise."*

The Master said:
*"When Heaven and Earth undergo transformation,*
*grasses and trees flourish.*
*When Heaven and Earth close in stillness,*
*virtuous men withdraw.*
*To gather the sack is without blame,*
*for it signifies restraint (谨),*
*and caution (慎) does no harm.*

Thus, the use of *expedience* is something the Sage finds difficult and cautious—
how can it not be guarded with care?
How can it not be guarded with care?

The *Classic* says:
*"The Dao endures without action,*
*yet nothing remains undone.*
*If lords and kings can uphold*
*this art of the Origin and the Mother,*
*all things shall naturally transform.*
*When transformation is complete,*
*I shall govern with the nameless simplicity (无名之朴).*
*The nameless simplicity,*
*too, shall not desire action.*
*Without desire, it remains tranquil—*
*thus the realm shall naturally rectify itself."*

The *Transmission* says:
*"The Dao endures as constant*
*because its essence is nameless,*
*thus it acts without action,*
*and its function is named,*
*thus it accomplishes all things without omission.*
*If lords and kings can uphold*
*this art of the Origin and the Mother,*
*then the principles of all things shall be attained,*
*and the affairs of the realm shall be set right—*
*this is what is meant by*
*'I act without action, yet the people transform themselves.'*

Once virtue/power and transformation become pure,
the realm attains clarity and tranquility.
If the emotions of profit and desire begin to sprout,
I shall firmly establish and rectify this great Dao
with its fundamental simplicity,
so that nothing may stir them.

The *Highest Virtue* (上德) acts without action,
yet nothing is left undone—
thus it aligns with the Dao.
The *Lower Virtue* (下德) acts with action,
yet something is left undone—
thus it aligns with virtue/power.

Those who attain virtue/power
must inevitably lose the Dao,
thus one who has the heart of non-action
shall naturally display the traces of non-action.
Future generations shall seek its traces
while forgetting its root—
thus they arrive at non-action
yet fall into action.
Hence it is said:
*'The nameless simplicity,*
*too, shall not desire action'*
—meaning to make both heart and trace forgotten,
thus reaching the *Mysterious of Mysteries* (玄之又玄).

If one can forget both heart and trace,
and harmonize with the mysterious principles,
then all under Heaven shall naturally fulfill their true nature,
and bear no burden from the traces of things.

The first chapter takes the constant Dao as its essence,
constant names as its function,
and culminates in the *Triply Mysterious* (重玄).
This chapter takes non-action as its essence,
and the fulfillment of all things as its function,
unifying them in the principle of *comprehensive forgetting* (兼忘).
The beginning and end are interconnected,
thus exhausting its essence and function.

*Transmission of the True Dao/Virtue Classic, Volume II ends.*
#1 *"亦将不欲"* (亦将不欲): The original text had three additional characters *"於不欲"* (於不欲)* after this sentence, which have been deleted according to the Zhi Hai edition.
#2 *"若在其前后"* (若在其前后): Possibly a corruption, should be *"若在乎下"* (若在乎下).

*Transmission of the True Dao/Virtue Classic, Volume III*
*Transmitted by Lu Xi Sheng (陆希声) of Wu Commandery (吴郡).*」

chunks.original_text: 经：上德不德，是以有德，下德不失德，是以无德。 上德无为而无以为，下德为之而有以为。 上仁为之而无以为，上义为之而有以为。 上礼为之而莫之应，则攘臂而仍之。 故失道而后德，失德而后仁，失仁而后义，失义而后礼。 夫礼者，忠信之薄而乱之首。 前识#1者，道之华而愚之始。 是以大丈夫处其厚不处其薄，居其实不居其华，故去彼取此。 传：上德合道，不以德称，无以而为，故有常德。 下德失道而同於德，有以而为，故无常德。 上德之用，法乎自然，故无以为而无为也。 下德之用，法乎无为，故有以为而为之也。 夫仁者兼爱，皆有为而为，能无以仁为功者，上也。 义者禁非，亦有为而为，能有以义为利者，上也。 何则？ 若以仁为功则滞於为仁矣，若不以义为利则徇於非义矣。 夫礼之上者，所以辨上下，定民志。 至於陈玉帛，尚往来，斯礼之末节也。 今礼敬於人，人未之答，彼诚失礼之微者。 我乃鲍然变色，奋肱而引之，则失礼复甚於彼矣。 夫礼所以防争，失之於末则反以起争，斯乃世俗之常情，不达礼之大本故也。 老氏举其失礼之甚，讥其起争之由，将使人反礼之本，复归於太一者耳。 《记》曰：爱人而不亲，则反其仁； 礼人而不答，则反其敬。 故克己复礼而不尤於人。 《易》曰：谦以制礼。 又曰：谦，德之柄。 苟能执谦之柄，复礼之始，则指撝而无不利，安有攘仍之失哉。 且上德无为自然合道，失於上德，法乎无为，故曰失道而后德耳。 夫法乎无为，德业着矣； 有为而为，仁功见矣； 裁而利之，上义明矣； 制而防之，上礼立矣。 故曰失德而后仁，失仁而后义，失义而后礼也。 夫失於彼者得於此，此天下之常理也。 故忠信之质衰於中，而祸乱之机兆，则制礼以防其乱，故礼居乱之首。 大道之华发於外，而愚昧之情或，则崇智以导其愚，故智为愚之始也。 前识者，智也。 智为先见之明，而照於未形之理者也。 然则仁义礼智皆圣人适时之用，所以与世污隆，随时升降者耳。 故执古御今，则以道德为之本，礼智为之末。 化今复古，则以礼制为其始，道德为其终，所谓损之又损之以至於无为者也。 夫豢豕为酒非以为祸，而酒之流祸生焉； 仁义礼智非以为乱，而治之弊乱至焉。 惑者不知利欲之为乱，乃欲归罪圣智，因谓绝而弃之，则可以复於上古之治，一何过哉，一何过哉。 故曰论礼於淳朴之代，非狂则悖； 忘礼於浇漓之日，非愚则诬。 在於寻流还源，去末归本，正礼义以反仁德，用有名而体无名，则自然之道不远而复矣。 所谓大丈夫者，且将断此而不疑，安处於道德之本，不滞於礼智之末者耳。 何为其然乎？ 作法於治，其弊犹乱； 作法於乱，弊将若何？ 故去彼华薄，取此厚实，斯乃执古御今之深旨也。 於乎礼亦有之，祭天一献，贵质也。 器用陶匏，贵素也。 明酒之用而玄酒之尚，莞箪之安而稿秸之设，皆贵本也，安可忽之哉。 经：昔之得一者，天得一以清，地得一以宁，神得一以灵，谷得一以盈，万物得一以生，侯王得一以为天下贞。 其致之一也，天无以清将恐裂，地无以宁将恐发，神无以灵将恐歇，谷无以盈将恐竭，万物无以生将恐灭，侯王无以贞而贵高将恐蹶。 故贵必以贱为本，高必以下为基。
chunks.translated_text:
*The True Dao/Virtue Classic, Volume III*

**The Classic:**
The highest virtue does not claim virtue—thus it truly has virtue.
The lowest virtue does not abandon virtue—thus it lacks virtue.
The highest virtue acts without striving, yet nothing is left undone—thus it has no striving.
The lowest virtue strives, yet nothing is accomplished—thus it has striving.

The highest benevolence acts without striving—thus it is truly benevolent.
The highest righteousness acts with striving—thus it is truly righteous.
The highest propriety acts with striving, yet none respond—so it forces arms and persists.
Thus, when the Dao is lost, virtue follows;
when virtue is lost, benevolence follows;
when benevolence is lost, righteousness follows;
when righteousness is lost, propriety follows.

For propriety, though thin as loyalty and trust,
is the first root of chaos.
Discernment#1, though the bloom of the Dao,
is the beginning of folly.
Hence, the true man dwells in its substance, not its bloom;
inhabits its depth, not its thinness—
thus he discards that and takes this.

**The Transmission:**
The highest virtue aligns with the Dao,
not claiming virtue, thus having constant virtue.
The lowest virtue loses the Dao yet clings to virtue—
claiming virtue, thus lacking constant virtue.
The highest virtue’s function follows Nature—
thus, without striving, it is without striving.
The lowest virtue’s function follows non-action—
thus, with striving, it strives.

Benevolence is universal love—
all actions are striving, yet he who does not claim benevolence as his deed is the highest.
Righteousness is the prohibition of wrong—
all actions are striving, yet he who does not claim righteousness as his gain is the highest.
Why so? If benevolence is claimed as a deed, then one is hindered by the act of benevolence itself.
If righteousness is not claimed as a gain, then one will yield to what is unrighteous.

For the highest propriety,
it serves to distinguish rank and settle the people’s resolve.
But when it comes to displaying jade and silk,
valuing etiquette and reciprocity—
these are the trivial extremities of propriety.
Now, if one reveres propriety toward others,
yet others do not respond,
he is indeed one who has slighted propriety.
But if I, in turn, change countenance and strain to draw him forth,
then my offense is far greater than his.
For propriety exists to prevent strife—
when lost to its trivialities, it instead provokes strife.
This is the common fate of the world,
those who do not grasp propriety’s great foundation.

The Master Lao held forth these extreme violations of propriety,
mocking their cause of strife,
to urge men to return to propriety’s root
and rejoin the *Great Unity* (太一).

*The Record* says:
Love others without intimacy—then you have inverted benevolence.
Revere propriety yet receive no response—then you have inverted respect.
Thus, conquer yourself and restore propriety without reproaching others.

*The Book of Changes* says:
Use humility to regulate propriety.
And again:
Humility is the handle of virtue.
If one can grasp humility’s handle,
the root of propriety restored,
then all will proceed without obstruction—
how could there be any loss from forcing or persisting?

Moreover, the highest virtue aligns with non-action by Nature—
when lost from the highest virtue,
it follows non-action—
thus it is said, *"When the Dao is lost, virtue follows."*

If one follows non-action,
virtue’s works are established;
if one acts with striving,
benevolence’s deeds appear;
if one restrains and benefits,
the highest righteousness is clear;
if one regulates and prevents,
the highest propriety is set.
Thus it is said,
*"When virtue is lost, benevolence follows;
when benevolence is lost, righteousness follows;
when righteousness is lost, propriety follows."*

For what is lost in one is gained in another—
this is the universal principle.
Thus, the essence of loyalty and trust decays within,
while the seeds of chaos take root—
so propriety is established to prevent its outbreak,
and propriety stands at the head of chaos.

The Dao’s bloom manifests externally,
while folly and confusion arise—
so discernment is exalted to guide the foolish.
Thus, discernment is the origin of folly.

Discernment is foresight’s clarity,
illuminating principles yet to take form.
Yet benevolence, righteousness, propriety, and discernment
are all the Sage’s timely applications,
to rise or fall with the times,
to flourish or decline with the age.
Thus, clinging to the ancient while governing the present,
the Dao and virtue are its foundation,
while propriety and discernment are its extremities.
Transforming the present to restore the ancient,
propriety’s regulation is its beginning,
while the Dao and virtue are its end—
this is what is meant by *"reduce it, reduce it, until it reaches non-action."*

To raise swine for wine is not to make wine a calamity,
yet wine’s spread brings calamity.
Benevolence, righteousness, propriety, and discernment
are not to make chaos,
yet their misuse brings chaos as a consequence.
The perplexed do not know that desire for gain is the source of chaos,
and so blame the Sage’s wisdom,
saying that to sever and abandon them
would restore the governance of ancient times—
how far astray are they, how far astray!

Thus it is said:
To discuss propriety in the age of purity—
either madness or perversity.
To forget propriety in the age of corruption—
either stupidity or slander.

In seeking the source and returning to the origin,
discarding trivialities and reclaiming the root,
restoring righteousness and propriety to return to benevolence and virtue,
employing named forms while dwelling in the formless—
then the Dao of Nature will not be distant before it is restored.

This is what is meant by the true man—
he will sever this without doubt,
dwelling securely in the foundation of the Dao and virtue,
not hindered by the extremities of propriety and discernment.
Why is this so? Laws established in governance still breed chaos;
laws established in chaos—what would their consequences be?
Thus, discard that which is trivial and superficial,
take this which is profound and substantial—
this is the deep intention of clinging to the ancient while governing the present.

Ah! Even propriety has its place—
offering sacrifices to Heaven with a single libation, valuing sincerity.
Using earthenware and gourds for vessels, valuing simplicity.
Revealing wine’s practical use while esteeming its mysterious worth,
settling coarse baskets with care while arranging reeds for adornment—
all these value the root.
How can they be neglected?

**The Classic:**
In ancient times, those who attained *Oneness* (一),
Heaven attained it and became clear,
Earth attained it and became tranquil,
The *Spirit* (神) attained it and became responsive,
The *Grains* (谷) attained it and became full,
All things attained it and flourished,
Rulers attained it and became steadfast for the world.

Their attainment was through Oneness—
Heaven without clarity would fear collapse,
Earth without tranquility would fear eruption,
The Spirit without responsiveness would fear extinction,
The Grains without fullness would fear depletion,
All things without flourishing would fear annihilation,
Rulers without steadfastness would fear ruin—
and so the noble would fear elevation.

Thus, nobility must have humility as its root,
elevation must have lowliness as its foundation—
so it takes this and discards that.

chunks.original_text: 是以侯王自谓孤、寡、不谷，此其以贱为本也。 非乎？ 故致数舆无舆，不欲琭琭如玉，珞珞如石。 传：夫一者，道之子，物之始也。 能抱其子，复其始，则万物莫不遂其生之理矣。 虽天道之与神明，地道之与山谷，莫不以得一之故而能清灵宁盈耳。 《易》曰：天下之动贞夫一。 故侯王得之则为天下贞，所以致之其道一也。 然唯其致之，不可恃之，故戒其无以此为也。 苟恃其清灵宁盈，则必将裂发歇竭矣。 於乎万物恃其生，天理必灭。 侯王恃其贞，贵高必蹶。 特加贵高之言，将戒侯王之深旨也。 亦既戒之，而又演之，曰其所以得贵为王侯，必以贱者为根本也。 其所以高居大位，必以下民为基址也。 至於孤寡不谷，皆下贱之称也，而侯王以此自称者，此以下贱为本之谓也。 穷极其致，何以明之？ 夫士农工商具於民，然后有国焉； 轮辕箱轴备於用，然后有舆焉。 今指舆而数之，则皆轮辕箱轴耳，不见有舆也。 指国而数之，则士农工商耳，不见有国也。 然则士农工商，国之贱下者也，国之所以存，以贱下为本耳。 故侯王当以贵自戒，不欲琭琭然如玉之贵异； 当以贱下为本，故宜珞珞然如石之凡贱也。 经：反者道之动，弱者道之用。 天下之物生於有，有生於无。 传：夫权也者，以反为动而合於正者也。 实也者，以弱为用而制於强者也。 天下之物皆生於有形，有形之物必生於无形。 天下之事皆生於有兆，有兆之事叉生於无兆。 故知反之为动，必生於弱之为用，则动微之几，必生於静冥之理。 然则几生於理，终归於理，权生於实，终反於实，此皆道之通变覆却相济者也。 经：上士闻道，勤而行之； 中士闻道，若存若亡； 下士闻道，大笑之，不笑不足以为道。 建言有之：明道若昧，进道若退，夷道若颣，上德若谷，大白若辱，广德若不足，建德若偷，质真若渝，大方无隅，大器晚成，大音希声，大象无形，道隐无名。 夫唯道，善贷且成。 传：《易》曰：形而上者谓之道。 道也者，通乎形外者也。 形而下者谓之器。 器也者，止乎形内者也。 上士知微知彰，通乎形外，故闻道而信，则勤行之。 中士在微彰之际，处道器之间，故闻道而疑信相半，故若存若亡。 下士知彰而不知微，止乎形内，故闻道则大笑之。 不唯笑之，且将非之矣。 夫道也者，微妙玄通，深不可识，苟不为下士所非笑，则不足以为真精之道矣。 然则为下士所非笑者，岂不以立言有云乎。 夫体道者，与日月合其贞明，而其光不耀，斯明道若昧也。 与天地合其易简，而其用不可为典要，斯夷道若颣也。 与四时合其运行，而其动必反於玄妙，斯进道若退也。 常处卑下，而终不可渝，斯上德若谷也。 常居溷浊，而终不可涅，斯大白若辱也。 衣被天下，而不有其仁，斯广德若不足也。 生畜万物，而不显其功，斯建德若偷也。 复其性以御其情，斯质真若渝也。 正乎内而行乎外，斯大方无隅也。 以若拙之匠，陶甄天下而不为近功，斯大器晚成也。 以不言之教，鼓动万物而不事小说，斯大音希声也。 事无事，莫睹其用，斯大象无形也。 为无为，莫识其体，斯道隐无名也。 夫唯善济贷於万物，而不责其报，是以万物受其生成而不知其德，故下士闻此道而笑之，不信其能若此耳。
chunks.translated_text:
Thus, the noble rulers call themselves *Lone* (孤), *Few* (寡), and *Not Grains* (不谷)—this is their way of taking lowliness as root.
Is it not so?
Hence, they do not seek the splendor of *glittering jade* (琭琭), nor the rigidity of *flint-like stone* (珞珞).

The *Classical* says:
The *One* (一) is the child of the *Dao/Way* (道), the origin of all things.
If one can embrace its child and restore its origin, then all things will naturally fulfill their *principle of life* (生之理).
Even the *Dao/Way* of Heaven and its *Divine Brilliance* (神明), the *Dao/Way* of Earth and its *Mountainous Depths* (山谷),
all achieve clarity and responsiveness, tranquility and fullness, because of their attainment of the *One*.

The *Book of Changes* (《易》) says: *"All movement under Heaven is rooted in the steadfastness of the One."*
Thus, when rulers attain it, they become steadfast for the world—
the means by which they attain it is through the *One Dao/Way*.
Yet, though they attain it,
they must not rely upon it—
therefore, they guard against making it their sole foundation.
If they rely upon clarity and responsiveness, tranquility and fullness,
then they will surely fear collapse and eruption, extinction and depletion.
Alas! All things rely upon their *principle of life*—
if they rely upon it, the *Heavenly Principle* (天理) will surely perish.
Rulers rely upon steadfastness—
if they rely upon it, their *nobility and elevation* (貴高) will surely falter.
The words *"nobility and elevation"* are added to warn of the profound intent for rulers.

They have both warned and expounded upon it, saying:
*"The reason rulers attain nobility and kingship is because they take the lowly as their root,
the reason they occupy high positions is because they take the common people as their foundation.
As for calling themselves Lone, Few, and Not Grains—
these are terms of lowliness,
yet rulers who use them to describe themselves
are truly taking lowliness as their root."*

To exhaust its meaning, how shall we explain it?
The *scholar* (士), *farmer* (农), *artisan* (工), and *merchant* (商) all exist within the people—
only then does the state exist.
The *wheels* (輪), *axles* (辕), *chests* (箱), and *shafts* (轴) are prepared for use—
only then does the carriage exist.
Now, if one points to the carriage and counts its parts,
they are but wheels, axles, chests, and shafts—
one does not see the carriage itself.
If one points to the state and counts its elements,
they are but scholars, farmers, artisans, and merchants—
one does not see the state itself.
Thus, the scholar, farmer, artisan, and merchant
are the lowly and base of the state—
the state’s existence depends upon the lowly and base as its root.
Hence, rulers should warn themselves against nobility,
not desiring the brilliance of jade-like splendor,
but should take the lowly and base as their root—
thus, they should be like flint-like stone in their common humility.

The *Classical* says:
*"The contrary is the movement of the Dao/Way,
the weak is its application.*
All things under Heaven arise from *Being* (有),
*Being* arises from *Non-Being* (无)."
The *Commentary* says:
*"The *power* (权) is that which, through contrariness, moves and aligns with the proper.
The *substance* (实) is that which, through weakness, applies and is governed by the strong.*
All things under Heaven arise from *having form* (有形),
*having form* must arise from *having no form* (无形).
All affairs under Heaven arise from *having signs* (有兆),
*having signs* must arise from *having no signs* (无兆).
Thus, knowing that contrariness is movement,
it must arise from weakness as application—
then the subtle beginning of motion
must arise from the principle of stillness and obscurity.
Yet, the subtle beginning of motion arises from principle,
and in the end, it returns to principle.
Power arises from substance,
and in the end, it returns to substance—
these are all the *universal transformations* (通变) of the Dao/Way,
the *reversals and recoveries* (覆却) that mutually aid each other.

The *Classical* says:
*"The superior person hears the Dao/Way and diligently practices it;
the middle person hears the Dao/Way and clings to it uncertainly;
the inferior person hears the Dao/Way and laughs at it—
if they do not laugh, it is not the Dao/Way."*

The *Commentary* builds upon this:
*"The Dao/Way, though clear, is as if obscured;
advancing the Dao/Way is as if retreating;
leveling the Dao/Way is as if crooked;
superior virtue is as if lacking;
great brightness is as if stained;
expansive virtue is as if insufficient;
established virtue is as if stolen;
pure truth is as if muddy;
the greatest square has no corners;
the greatest vessel takes long to form;
the greatest sound is faint;
the greatest form is shapeless;
the Dao/Way is hidden and nameless."*

The Dao/Way alone is good at lending and completing.
The *Commentary* says:
The *Book of Changes* (《易》) states:
*"That which is above form is called the Dao/Way.
The Dao/Way is that which transcends form.
That which is below form is called the vessel.
The vessel is that which is confined within form.*
The superior person knows the subtle and the manifest,
transcends form, and thus hears the Dao/Way and believes it—
they diligently practice it.
The middle person is caught between the subtle and the manifest,
dwelling in the space between the Dao/Way and the vessel—
thus, when they hear the Dao/Way, they doubt and half-believe—
hence, they cling to it uncertainly.
The inferior person knows only the manifest and not the subtle,
is confined within form—
thus, when they hear the Dao/Way, they laugh at it.
Not only do they laugh,
but they would also deny it.
The Dao/Way is subtle, mysterious, and profoundly penetrating,
deep beyond recognition—
if it were not laughed at and denied by the inferior,
then it would not be the true and refined Dao/Way.
Yet, why is it laughed at and denied by the inferior?
It is because the *Commentary* says:

*"The one who embodies the Dao/Way,
aligns with the Heavenly Principle of the sun and moon in their steadfast clarity,
yet their light does not dazzle—
this is the Dao/Way, though clear, as if obscured.
They align with the Heavenly Principle of Heaven and Earth in their ease and simplicity,
yet their application cannot be made into laws and decrees—
this is the Dao/Way, though level, as if crooked.
They align with the Heavenly Principle of the four seasons in their movement,
yet their action must return to the mysterious and profound—
this is advancing the Dao/Way as if retreating.
They constantly dwell in lowliness,
yet are never corrupted—
this is superior virtue as if lacking.
They constantly reside in filth and impurity,
yet are never stained—
this is great brightness as if stained.
They clothe and shelter all under Heaven,
yet do not claim credit for their kindness—
this is expansive virtue as if insufficient.
They nurture and sustain all things,
yet do not display their efforts—
this is established virtue as if stolen.
They restore their nature to govern their emotions—
this is pure truth as if muddy.
They are correct within and act properly without—
this is the greatest square having no corners.
With the skill of a clumsy artisan,
they mold and refine all under Heaven yet do not seek immediate results—
this is the greatest vessel taking long to form.
With teaching that is not spoken,
they stir and move all things yet do not indulge in trifling words—
this is the greatest sound being faint.
In affairs where there is no affair,
one does not see their use—
this is the greatest form being shapeless.
In doing that which is *Non-Doing* (无为),
one does not recognize their body—
this is the Dao/Way being hidden and nameless.

The Dao/Way alone is good at lending and completing to all things,
yet does not demand repayment—
thus, all things receive its nurturing and completion yet do not know its virtue,
and so the inferior person hears this Dao/Way and laughs at it,
not believing it could be so."*

chunks.original_text: 经：道生一，一生二，二生三，三生万物。 万物负阴而抱阳，冲炁以为和。 人之所恶，唯孤、寡、不谷，而王公以自称。 故物或损之而益，或益之而损。 人之所教，亦我义教之，强梁者不得其死，吾将以为教父。 天下之至柔，驰骋天下之至坚。 无有入於无间。 吾是以知无为之有益。 不言之教，无为之益，天下希及之。 传：夫真精之体，生妙物之用，炁形既具，万物生焉。 夫阴阳相交而为冲炁，冲炁运化而成万物。 然万物之生也，莫不背阴而向阳，冲炁行其中，所以和顺其生理也。 圣人立教之指，必原夫天地之道，穷万物之理，然后知人之生也，亦以冲炁为主焉。 何以明之？ 夫人受天地之中以生，所谓命也，其始有精爽，谓之魂魄。 魄者，阴也。 魂者，阳也。 阴阳化淳，而冲和之炁行乎其间，所以成形神也。 故冲和之炁全，则神与形相得，神与形相得则为生。 冲和之炁散，则神与形相离，神与形相离则为死。 死者不可复生，散者不可复全，故必能养其浩然之炁，然后可以合於自然之道。 《易》不云乎，天地之大德曰生。 生也者，盖圣人之所重也。 圣人之所以重其生者，何将以行道也。 道也者，域中之所尊也。 虽大包天地，细入毫芒，要而言之，在於身心而已。 是以为道之人务治身心之要，治身心之要在处众人之所恶。 然则孤寡不谷皆众人之所恶，而王公自以为称者，将以损身心之强梁，而求益於道德者也。 在《易》损之为善，莫善於惩忿窒欲。 惩忿窒欲则其心日明，其心日明则可以益於理矣。 为益之美，莫美於迁善改过。 迁善改过则其身日正，其身日正则可以损其事矣。 所谓物或损之而益，或益之而损也。 夫人之所以教，教人日益； 我亦教人，教人日损。 故损之又损之，以至於无为也。 夫道以柔弱为用，不与物争，故物莫能与之争，所谓不损益之者也。 强梁者以暴害物，物亦害之，故不得尽其生理，所谓莫益之或击之也。 吾知彼强梁为万物所恶，故以此柔弱为众教之父。 何以明之？ 夫水以至柔为用，而穿於石之至坚； 炁以无形为体，而入於物之无间。 是知有为之教本於事，以刚健为主； 无为之教本於理，以柔顺为先。 吾见水之攻至坚，炁黑之入无间，是以知无为之有益，有为之有损也。 夫行多言之教，滞有为之事，则有为之有损也。 行不言之教，通无为之理，则无为之有益也。 多言之教，有为之损，举天下皆是也。 不言之教，无为之益，则天下希及之。 於乎知我者希，则我者贵信矣。 经：名与身孰亲？ 身与货孰多？ 得与亡孰病？ 是故甚爱必大费，多藏必厚亡。 知足不辱，知止不殆，可以长久。 传：夫名者，立身之表也。 有其实则身见尊於当时，名亦扬於后世。 苟以矫激为之，不足施於事实，则名虽闻人#2，身必弃於有道矣。 货者，发身之资也。 得所用则身以好施见重，货不为己而积。 苟以贪冒得之，不能散於仁惠，则货虽满堂，身必薄於有德矣。 得窃名黩货之讥，而亡其修身约己之道，二者孰为病乎？ 故甚爱名者叉生伪，则大伤其实矣。 多藏货者必招盗，则厚失其资矣。 故知足则不贪货，知止则不贪名。 不贪货则不辱，不责贪则不殆。 夫唯如此，则其名可以长有，其货可以久守矣。

**Scripture:**
The Dao/Way gives birth to One,
One gives birth to Two,
Two gives birth to Three,
Three gives birth to all things.
All things bear yin and embrace yang,
and through the interplay of *qi* achieve harmony.

What people detest—
the titles *Orphan, Widow, and Without Grain*—
yet kings and lords claim them as their own.
Thus, some things are diminished to be enhanced,
while others are enhanced to be diminished.

What people teach as *benefit*,
I teach as *subduing*—
the violent and domineering shall not meet their end,
and I shall make them my teacher.

The most yielding in all under Heaven
overcomes the most rigid in all under Heaven.
There is no entry into the unspanned.

Thus, I know the virtue of *Non-Doing*.

The teaching of *Non-Speaking*,
the benefit of *Non-Doing*—
few under Heaven attain it.

**Commentary:**
The essence of true *qi* generates the wondrous functions of all things.
When the form of *qi* is complete, all things arise.
Yin and yang intermingle to form the harmonizing *qi*,
and this harmonizing *qi* circulates and transforms to produce all things.

Yet when all things are born,
they inevitably turn their backs to yin and face yang,
with harmonizing *qi* coursing between them—
this is how their natural order is maintained.

The Sage establishes teaching by tracing the Dao/Way of Heaven and Earth,
and exhausting the principles of all things,
and thus knows that human life too is governed by harmonizing *qi*.

How may this be made clear?
Humans receive the central *qi* of Heaven and Earth at birth—
this is called *fate*.
At its beginning, there is a luminous vitality, called *hun* and *po*.
The *po* is yin,
the *hun* is yang.
When yin and yang blend in purity,
harmonizing *qi* flows between them,
and thus the form and spirit are perfected.

If harmonizing *qi* is preserved whole,
spirit and form are in accord,
and spirit and form in accord mean life.
If harmonizing *qi* is scattered,
spirit and form separate,
and spirit and form separated mean death.

The dead cannot be revived,
the scattered cannot be restored—
thus, one must nurture the vast harmonizing *qi*
to align with the Dao/Way of Nature.

Does not the *Classic of Changes* say:
*The greatest virtue of Heaven and Earth is generation.*
Generation is what the Sage holds most precious.
The Sage values life so highly
because through it the Dao/Way is realized.

The Dao/Way is what the world reveres—
though it encompasses Heaven and Earth,
and penetrates the finest hairs,
its essence lies in body and mind alone.

Thus, those who follow the Dao/Way cultivate the vital principles of body and mind,
and the key to this lies in dwelling where people detest.

Now, *Orphan, Widow, and Without Grain*—
these are what people detest,
yet kings and lords claim them as their own,
for they seek to diminish the violent and domineering
and benefit from virtue and power.

In the *Classic of Changes*, *Diminishing* is a virtue,
and none excel it more than restraining anger and suppressing desire.
To restrain anger and suppress desire
is to clarify the mind daily,
and a clarified mind can benefit from principle.

The finest enhancement is to change what is bad and amend what is wrong.
To change what is bad and amend what is wrong
is to rectify the body daily,
and a rectified body can diminish its affairs.

This is what is meant by:
*Some things are diminished to be enhanced,
others enhanced to be diminished.*

People’s teaching is to increase daily,
but I teach to diminish daily.
Thus, diminish again and again,
until one reaches *Non-Doing*.

The Dao/Way employs softness and weakness in action,
does not contend with things,
and thus nothing can contend with it—
this is the *Non-Diminishing, Non-Enhancing*.

The violent and domineering harm things violently,
and things harm them in return,
so they cannot fulfill their natural order—
this is the *Not-Enhanced, but Struck*.

I know that the violent and domineering are detested by all things,
so I take this softness and weakness as the parent of all teachings.

How may this be made clear?
Water, though supremely yielding in use,
erodes the most rigid stone.
*Qi*, though formless in essence,
penetrates the unspanned in all things.

Thus, I see water attacking the most rigid,
and *qi* entering the unspanned,
and so I know the benefit of *Non-Doing*
and the harm of *Doing*.

To practice the teaching of much speech,
to be entangled in *Doing*—
this is the harm of *Doing*.

To practice the teaching of *Non-Speaking*,
to embody the principle of *Non-Doing*—
this is the benefit of *Non-Doing*.

The teaching of much speech brings the harm of *Doing*—
all under Heaven are thus.
The teaching of *Non-Speaking* brings the benefit of *Non-Doing*—
yet few under Heaven attain it.

Ah! Those who truly know me are rare,
so I am held in trustworthy esteem.

**Scripture:**
Which is closer to me—*name* or *body*?
Which is more abundant—*body* or *wealth*?
Which brings greater harm—*gain* or *loss*?

Thus, the more one loves excessively,
the greater the expenditure.
The more one hoards,
the greater the loss.

To know sufficiency is to avoid disgrace,
to know cessation is to avoid peril—
thus one may endure long.

**Commentary:**
*Name* is the banner of one’s standing.
If it is genuine, the body is honored in its time,
and the name endures in posterity.
But if it is contrived and exaggerated,
unworthy of reality,
though the name may be heard by others,
the body will be abandoned by those of the Dao.

*Wealth* is the resource for one’s livelihood.
If used properly, the body is esteemed for generous giving,
and wealth is not hoarded for oneself.
But if acquired through greed and deceit,
and not dispersed in benevolence and kindness,
though wealth may fill the halls,
the body will be slighted by those of virtue.

To lose both the censure of usurping names and squandering wealth,
while neglecting the way of cultivating oneself and restraining desires—
which of these brings greater harm?

Thus, those who love *name* excessively
give rise to deceit,
and thus greatly damage reality.
Those who hoard wealth excessively
invite thieves,
and thus greatly lose their resources.

To know sufficiency is to not covet wealth,
to know cessation is to not covet *name*.
Not coveting wealth avoids disgrace,
not coveting *name* avoids peril.

Only thus can one’s *name* endure,
and one’s wealth be long preserved.

chunks.original_text: 经：大成若缺，其用不弊。 大盈若冲，其用不穷。 大直若屈，大巧若拙，大辩若讷。 躁胜寒，静胜热，清静为天下正。 传：夫圣人道济天下，而犹虑一物不得其所，则成众务而不弊矣； 德充四海，而不敢介然自矜於怀，则应万机而不穷矣。 行至易之道而不径庭，因自成之器而不雕镌，陈至当之理而不文饰。 夫如此，则物遂其性，人尽其能，天下之事不劳而自定矣。 究其所以然者，皆自然而胜耳。 犹躁作者胜祁寒，静正者胜祁暑，非有心於寒暑，而寒暑不能侵之。 故我无为而民自化，我好静而民自正。 天下之动贞夫一，故清静可以为天下正也。 经：天下有道，却走马以粪； 天下无道，戎马生於郊。 罪莫大於可欲，祸莫大於不知足，咎莫大於欲得。 故知足之足，常足矣。 传：夫天下有道之世，天子则守在四夷，诸侯则守在邻国，虽有甲兵无所用，虽有健马无所乘。 百姓顺其教化，复於农桑，辟污莱以艺树，粪田畴而播殖，故民咸安其土，而敦其亲矣。 天下无道之时，天子则外攘四夷，诸侯则外侵邻国，故兵甲动於境内，戎马驰於四郊。 百姓困於力役，失其本业，桑梓尽於樵薪，荆棘生於陇亩，民咸去其乡而叛其君矣。 於乎无道之君毒痛天下，原其所以其恶有三心。 见可欲非理而求，故罪莫大焉； 求而不已必害於人，故祸莫大焉； 欲而必得，其心愈炽，故咎莫重焉。 然自非圣人不能无欲，欲则不能无求，求而不知足，祸之甚者也。 於乎未有多求而多得之者，故求而知足者，其求必寡则易供，故其求常足矣。 经：不出户，而知天下； 不窥牖，而见天道。 其出弥远，其知弥少。 是以圣人不行而知，不见而名，不为而成。 传：夫圣人之为治也，必推其身心以及於天下，故当食而思天下之饥，当衣而思天下之寒，爱其亲以及天下之老，爱其子以及天下之幼。 夫如此，不俟出户而天下可知矣。 夫圣人之治也，必反诸身心以合於天道，故己好生则知天道之生万物也，己成务则知天道之成四时也，己乐善则知天道之与善人也。 天以悬象示其道，圣人亦以身心合於道，又安用窥牖而后见天道哉。 夫不能反推於身心，而嚣嚣然自以天下为己任，劳其神，苦其形，孜孜矻矻有为於天下之事者，吾见其不能为治矣。 何者？ 夫天下之事一日万机，不能秉要执本，而务治其末，则形神劳矣。 夫神大劳则竭，形大劳则弊，形神俱劳则危殆及之矣。 徒勤劳於末流，竟不得其万一，是以其出弥远，其知弥少。 故《记》曰：欲治天下，先治其国； 欲治其国，先治其家； 欲治其家，先治其身； 欲治其身，先治其心； 欲治其心，先诚其意。 故君子不诚无物，皆反推於身心之谓也。 夫不行天下而能察知人情，不见天象而能名命天道，则不为勤劳之事，而能成乎至治，反推身心故也。 孔子曰：唯天为大，唯尧则之。 又曰：无为而治者，其舜也欤。 此之谓也。 经：为学日益，为道日损。 损之又损之，以至於无为。 无为而无不为。 取天下常以无事，及其有事，不足以取天下。 传：夫为学者，博闻多识，以通於理，故日益。 为道者，秉要执本，以简於事，故日损。 夫理明则事定，故学之日益，实资道之日损也。 夫浊於乱政，静之可以徐清，故损之在渐，不可顿去，则损之又损之也。

**经:**
The greatest fullness appears as if incomplete—
its use is inexhaustible.
The greatest abundance seems empty—
its use is boundless.
The most upright seems bent,
the most skillful seems clumsy,
the most eloquent seems tongue-tied.

Agitation overcomes cold,
stillness overcomes heat—
thus, clarity and tranquility are the Way’s foundation for all under Heaven.

**传:**
The Sage’s Dao nourishes all under Heaven,
yet fears even one thing left unplaced—
thus, all affairs are accomplished without exhaustion.
Virtue fills the four seas,
yet does not dare to swell with self-conceit—
thus, all affairs are managed without depletion.

Walking the Way of utmost ease yet never straying,
relying on self-perfected instruments without carving,
laying out the most fitting principles without embellishment—
thus, things follow their nature,
people fulfill their capacities,
and the world’s affairs settle without effort.

Examine why this is so—
it is simply the power of spontaneity.
Like agitation overcoming bitter cold,
stillness overcoming scorching heat—
not by contriving cold or heat,
yet cold and heat cannot assail it.

Thus, without action, the people transform themselves;
without preference for stillness, the people align themselves.
All movement under Heaven originates from One—
thus, clarity and tranquility can govern all under Heaven.

**经:**
When the Way prevails in the world,
warhorses are driven out to manure fields.
When the Way is lost in the world,
warhorses breed in the suburbs.

No guilt is greater than craving what is improper,
no calamity is greater than insatiability,
no fault is graver than demanding possession.
Thus, the sufficiency of sufficiency is always sufficient.

**传:**
In an age where the Way prevails,
the Son of Heaven guards against the four barbarians,
the feudal lords guard against neighboring states—
though arms and steeds exist, they serve no purpose.
The people follow their teachings,
return to farming and sericulture,
clear the wilds to plant trees,
manure the fields and sow seeds—
thus, the people cherish their land
and strengthen their kinship.

When the Way is lost,
the Son of Heaven repels the four barbarians,
the feudal lords invade neighboring states—
thus, arms stir within the borders,
warhorses gallop through the suburbs.
The people weary from labor,
abandon their livelihoods,
mulberry groves turn to firewood,
briers and thorns grow in the fields—
the people flee their homelands and betray their lords.

Alas, the tyranny of the Wayless ruler poisons all under Heaven.
Trace its origin—three evils of the heart:
Seeking what is improper yet unjust—
thus, no guilt is greater.
Seeking without restraint harms others—
thus, no calamity is greater.
Demanding possession only inflames the heart—
thus, no fault is heavier.

Yet, only the Sage can be without desire.
Desire leads to seeking,
seeking without sufficiency brings the greatest calamity.
Alas, none have ever sought much and gained much—
thus, those who seek with sufficiency
seek little and thus supply easily,
and their seeking is ever sufficient.

**经:**
Without stepping outside,
one knows all under Heaven.
Without peering through windows,
one perceives the Way of Heaven.
The farther one goes,
the less one knows.
Thus, the Sage acts without moving,
names without seeing,
accomplishes without doing.

**传:**
The Sage’s governance
extends from self and heart to all under Heaven—
thus, when eating, think of the world’s hunger;
when clothing, think of the world’s cold;
love for one’s parents extends to the world’s aged;
love for one’s children extends to the world’s young.
Thus, without leaving home,
one knows all under Heaven.

The Sage’s governance
returns to self and heart to align with Heaven’s Way—
thus, delighting in life reveals Heaven’s nurturing of all things,
completing tasks reveals Heaven’s perfecting of the four seasons,
favoring goodness reveals Heaven’s favor toward the virtuous.
Heaven displays its symbols to manifest its Way,
the Sage aligns self and heart with the Way—
why gaze through windows to perceive Heaven’s Way?

Those who cannot reflect inward,
yet clamorously take all under Heaven as their burden,
exhaust their spirit,
torment their form,
toiling ceaselessly in worldly affairs—
I see they cannot govern.

Why? The world’s affairs are myriad daily,
yet if they grasp not the essentials,
fixate on trifles,
their form and spirit grow weary.
When the spirit is overtaxed, it is depleted;
when the form is overtaxed, it is worn;
when both are overtaxed, peril follows.
Laboring in trivialities yet never attaining even a fraction—
thus, the farther they go, the less they know.

Hence the *Record* says:
To govern the world, first govern one’s state;
to govern one’s state, first govern one’s family;
to govern one’s family, first govern oneself;
to govern oneself, first govern one’s heart;
to govern one’s heart, first rectify one’s intentions.
Thus, the noble one without sincerity achieves nothing—
all must return to self and heart.

Without traversing the world yet knowing human nature,
without observing celestial omens yet naming Heaven’s Way—
without toiling in affairs yet achieving perfect governance—
this is the power of reflecting on self and heart.

Confucius said:
Only Heaven is vast—
only Yao followed it.
He also said:
To govern without action—
was it not Shun?

This is what is meant.

**经:**
For learning, daily increase;
for the Dao, daily decrease.
Decrease again, decrease again,
until reaching non-action.
Through non-action, nothing remains undone.
Taking the world with non-interference,
when interference arises,
it is insufficient to take the world.

**传:**
The scholar broadens knowledge and accumulates insight
to grasp principles—
thus, daily increase.
The Daoist holds fast to the essentials,
simplifies affairs—
thus, daily decrease.

When principles are clear, affairs settle—
thus, the scholar’s daily increase
relies on the Daoist’s daily decrease.

To calm turbulent governance,
stillness can gradually clarify—
thus, decrease is gradual,
not to be removed abruptly—
hence, decrease again, decrease again.

chunks.original_text: 安於弊俗，动之可以徐生，故损之至乎无为，则能无不为矣。 夫有为者，缘人情而作之法制，故有事。 有事则民劳，民劳则叛之。 无为者，因物性而辅之自然，故无事。 无事则民逸，民逸则归之。 夫圣人之心常虑一物失其所，将欲救弊乱之要，在於取天下人之心。 取天下人之心，在使其自来归之耳。 故为无为，事无事，俗化清静，则民乐推而不厌。 若有为有事，政烦民劳，则百姓望而畏之，故不足以取天下之心也。 经：圣人无常心，以百姓心为心。 善者吾善之，不善者吾亦善之，得善矣。 信者吾信之，不信者吾亦信之，得信矣。 圣人在天下惵惵，为天下浑其心，百姓皆注其耳目，圣人皆孩之。 传：圣人体道无为，物感则应，应其所感，故无常心。 然百姓之心常欲安其生而遂其性，圣人常使人人得其所欲，岂非以百姓心为心乎？ 苟百姓有好善之心，圣人亦应之以好善，其本善者，吾因以善辅之。 苟有不善之心，吾亦因而善待之，使感吾善，亦化而为善，则天下无不善，百姓皆得所欲之善矣。 至於百姓有好信之者，吾亦以此化之，则百姓皆得所欲之信，而天下无不信矣。 故圣人在天下，惵惵然应於物感，未尝少息，而其心浑然与天下为一，未尝自有所为。 故仲尼之所绝者有四，谓毋意、毋必、毋固、毋我。 是以能无可无不可，无为无不为，故百姓皆注其耳目於圣人，若婴儿之仰慈母，圣人视之唯恐其伤也。 经：出生入死。 生之徒十有三，死之徒十有三，人之生，动之死地亦十有三。 夫何故？ 以其生生之厚。

「。
　　**Experience:** Resting in flawed customs, movement can gradually bring forth change—
thus, decrease until reaching non-action,
and then one can achieve nothing left undone.

　　**The Way of the Sage:**
The one who acts relies on human inclinations to establish laws and regulations,
so there is interference.
Interference exhausts the people,
and exhaustion leads to rebellion.
The one who does not act follows the natural inclinations of things,
supporting their inherent spontaneity,
so there is no interference.
No interference brings ease to the people,
and ease leads them to return willingly.

　　The Sage’s mind ever considers
one thing out of place—
to address flaws and chaos,
the key lies in winning the hearts of the people.
Winning the hearts of the people
means letting them come willingly of their own accord.
Thus, through non-action, no interference,
and customs transformed into clarity and stillness,
the people take delight in being guided
without ever growing weary.

　　If there is action and interference,
government becomes burdensome and the people weary,
then the populace will recoil in fear
and thus it is insufficient to win the hearts of the people.

　　**Experience:** The Sage has no fixed heart,
but takes the hearts of the people as their own.
If they are virtuous, I nurture their virtue;
if they are not virtuous, I also nurture them with virtue—
thus, virtue is attained.
If they are trustworthy, I trust them;
if they are not trustworthy, I also trust them—
thus, trust is attained.

　　The Sage moves through the world in humble reverence,
unifying the hearts of the people,
while all the people focus their ears and eyes on the Sage,
as if the Sage were their tender child.
　　**Transmission:** The Sage embodies the Dao and does nothing,
responding only to the stirrings of things—
responding to what is stirred,
thus having no fixed heart.

　　Yet the hearts of the people
ever seek to secure their lives
and fulfill their nature.
The Sage ever ensures that each person
receives what they desire—
is this not taking the hearts of the people as their own?

　　If the people have a heart for virtue,
the Sage also responds with virtue to nurture them—
those inherently virtuous,
I assist with virtue to reinforce their goodness.
If the people have a heart for non-virtue,
I also treat them with virtue,
so that they feel my goodness
and transform, becoming virtuous—
then the world has no one who is not virtuous,
and the people all attain the virtue they desire.

　　As for the people who have a heart for trust,
I also transform them with this,
so that the people all attain the trust they desire,
and the world has no one who is untrustworthy.

　　Thus, the Sage moves through the world,
humble and responsive to the stirrings of things,
never resting,
yet their heart is unified with the world,
never acting for themselves.

　　Hence, Confucius’ four prohibitions:
Do not impose your will,
do not be rigid,
do not be obstinate,
do not be self-centered.
Thus, they can have no preferences,
no fixed course of action,
no interference,
no non-action—
so the people focus their ears and eyes on the Sage,
as a babe gazes upon its loving mother,
and the Sage fears only that they might be harmed.

　　**Experience:** Born to life, born to death.
Those born to life are thirteen in ten,
those born to death are thirteen in ten,
and those born to life,
when moved, also die thirteen in ten.
Why so?
Because the abundance of life’s vitality
leads to death’s domain.»

chunks.original_text: 盖闻善摄生者，陆行不遇兕虎，入军不避甲兵。 兕无所投其角，虎无所措其爪，兵无所容其刃。 夫何故？ 以其无死地。 传：夫生必有死，理之常也，达生死之理，则能安其常。 苟违其常，则越於生理。 越於生理，则陷於死地必矣。 然则知生有常理，不违理以存其生者，十中有三人耳。 知死亦常理，不违理以避其死者，十中亦三人耳。 若乃爱其生，违理而存之则反失，恶其死，违理而避之则反得者，亦如之。 何为其然？ 求生之厚越於生理，是以动而乖常，则之於死地。 故善摄生者则不然，知生有常理，则守道抱德而不厚其生； 知死亦常理，则乐天知命而不忧其死。 生死不能动其心，患难不能夺其志，则陆行遇挚兽而不惊，入军冒白刃而不詟，虽处患难与不遇同。 何以致其然耶？ 有心害物，物亦害之； 有信及物，物亦信之。 我无心害物，故兕虎无所投其爪角； 有信及人，故甲兵无所容其锋刃。 是知生理不存於中，则死地不见於前。 仲尼曰：忠信则水火可蹈。 盖近之矣。 经：道生之，德畜之，物形之，势成之。 是以万物莫不尊道而贵德。 道之尊，德之贵，夫莫之爵而常自然。 故道生之畜之，长之育之，亭之毒之，养之覆之。 生而不有，为而不恃，长而不宰，是谓玄德。 传：夫物生而后畜，畜而后形，形而后成。 其所由生者，道也； 其所以畜者，德也； 形其村者，事也； 成其用者，势也。 万物以能生，故尊道； 以能畜，故贵德。 道德以生畜之，故自然为万物所仰，岂有授之爵位而后见尊贵哉。 然道者真精之体，德者妙物之用，体可以兼用，用不可以兼体。 道可以兼德，德不可以兼道。 故禀其精谓之生，含其炁谓之畜，遂其形谓之长，字其材谓之育，权其成谓之亭，量其用谓之毒，保其和谓之养，护其伤谓之覆，此之谓大道。 既生之而不执有，既为之而不矜恃，既长之而不宰制，此之谓玄德。 营魄章言人同於道德，今此章言道德同於人，是以其辞同而其理通也。 经：天下有始，以为天下母。 既得其母，以知其子。 既知其子，复守其母。 殁身不殆。 传：天下万物固有所始，始天下者，其唯无名乎。 天下万物固有所生，生万物者，其唯有名乎。 然则无名为天下之始，有名为万物之母。 夫无名有名，存乎体用，用因体生，故复以无名为有名之母也。 故曰天下有始，以为天下母，即道生一也。 夫一为道之子，道为一之母。 道谓真精之体，一谓妙物之用。 既得其体，以知其用。 既得其用，复守其体。 体用冥一，应感不穷，然后可以无为而治，故能殁身不殆也。 经：塞其兑，闭其门，终身不勤。 开其兑，济其事，终身不救。 见小曰明，守柔曰强。 用其光，复归其明，无遗身殃，是谓袭常。 传：兑者，嗜欲所之生也。 门者，云为之所由也。 以性正情，则嗜欲之原塞矣； 以理正事，则云为之路闭矣。 夫如此，然后可以无为无不为，故终身不复劳也。 开其源而弗塞，则长其嗜欲之情； 通其路而弗闭，则济其云为之事。 如此则形神俱劳，终身不可救矣。 知塞兑闭门之术，是见於微小也。 挫嗜欲之锐，解云为之纷，是守其柔弱也。 守柔弱则物不能加，可谓强矣。 见微小则事不能昏，可谓明矣。 明者内景谓体也，光者外照谓用也。
chunks.translated_text:
The cover of the *Daoist Classic of Vitality* states:

*"The adept at preserving life*
walks upon land without fearing rhinoceros or tiger,
enters battle without shunning armor and weapons.
The rhinoceros finds no place to hurl its horn,
the tiger finds no place to strike with its claws,
the weapons find no place to lodge their blades.
Why so?
Because there are no grounds for death within them.

**Scripture:** Life must inevitably meet death—
this is the natural order.
To grasp the order of life and death,
one must accept it as constant.

If one defies this order,
they stray beyond the bounds of vitality.
Straying beyond the bounds of vitality,
they must inevitably fall into death’s domain.
Yet even so, those who know life’s order
and do not defy it to preserve their own—
three in ten.
Those who know death’s order
and do not defy it to avoid death—
three in ten as well.
But if they love life and defy the order to preserve it,
they lose it instead;
if they hate death and defy the order to avoid it,
they gain it instead—
the same holds true.
How does this come about?
Because the pursuit of life’s excess
transgresses beyond its natural bounds,
and thus, when moved from constancy,
they are drawn into death’s domain.

Hence, the adept at preserving life is different:
knowing life’s order, they uphold the *Dao* and embrace *virtue*
without indulging in life’s excess;
knowing death’s order, they find joy in *Heaven’s* ways
and accept their *fate* without fearing death.
Life and death cannot sway their heart,
calamities cannot shake their resolve,
so they walk upon land and meet fierce beasts
without alarm,
enter battle and brave the sharp blades
without flinching—
though facing hardship and misfortune alike.
How do they achieve this?
If one harms with their heart,
things will harm them in return;
if one trusts with their sincerity,
things will trust them in return.
I do not harm with my heart,
so rhinoceros and tiger find no place to strike with claws or horns;
I trust with my sincerity,
so armor and weapons find no place to lodge their blades.
Thus, when life’s order does not dwell within,
death’s domain does not appear before.

*The Master Zhongni* said:
‘*Loyalty* and *trustworthiness* make even fire and water passable.’
This is indeed close to the truth.

**Scripture:** The *Dao* gives birth to them,
*virtue* nurtures them,
things shape their form,
and *power* completes their function.
Thus, all things revere the *Dao* and honor *virtue*.
The *Dao’s* reverence,
the *virtue’s* honor—
none bestow them upon it,
yet they arise naturally and everlastingly.

Therefore, the *Dao* gives birth and nurtures,
lengthens and matures,
shelters and poisons,
rears and protects.
It gives birth without possession,
acts without reliance,
lengthens without control—
this is called *Mysterious Virtue*.

**Scripture:** Things are born and then nurtured,
nurtured and then shaped,
shaped and then completed.
That which gives birth to them is the *Dao*;
that which nurtures them is *virtue*;
that which shapes their forms is *affairs*;
that which completes their function is *power*.
All things honor the *Dao* because it gives birth,
and they revere *virtue* because it nurtures.
The *Dao* and *virtue* give birth and nurture,
so they are naturally revered by all things—
how could they be honored only after titles and ranks are conferred?

Yet the *Dao* is the essence of the true subtlety,
and *virtue* is the function of the wondrous.
The essence can encompass the function,
but the function cannot encompass the essence.
The *Dao* can encompass *virtue*,
but *virtue* cannot encompass the *Dao*.
Thus, receiving its essence is called *birth*,
embracing its *qi* is called *nurture*,
fulfilling its form is called *lengthening*,
marking its substance is called *maturing*,
balancing its completion is called *sheltering*,
measuring its function is called *poisoning*,
preserving its harmony is called *rearing*,
guarding its injury is called *protecting*—
this is called the *Great Dao*.
Having given birth without clinging to possession,
having acted without boasting of reliance,
having lengthened without controlling—
this is called *Mysterious Virtue*.

The *Chapter of Vital Essence* speaks of how humans align with *Dao* and *virtue*,
while this chapter speaks of how *Dao* and *virtue* align with humans,
thus their words are similar yet their meaning is unified.

**Scripture:** The world has a beginning,
which we call the *Mother of the World*.
Having obtained this *Mother*,
one knows her offspring.
Having known the offspring,
one returns to guard the *Mother*—
thus, one’s body remains unharmed through life’s end.

**Scripture:** The world’s myriad things indeed have a beginning,
and the beginning of all things—
is it not the *Nameless*?
All things indeed have a source,
and the source that gives birth to all—
is it not the *Named*?
Thus, the *Nameless* is the world’s beginning,
and the *Named* is all things’ *Mother*.
The *Nameless* and the *Named* exist in essence and function,
for function arises from essence,
so the *Nameless* is also the *Mother* of the *Named*.

Therefore, it is said:
‘The world has a beginning,
which we call the *Mother of the World*’—
this is the *Dao* giving birth to One.
One is the *Dao’s* offspring,
the *Dao* is One’s *Mother*.
The *Dao* refers to the essence of true subtlety,
and One refers to the function of wondrous things.
Having obtained its essence,
one knows its function.
Having obtained its function,
one returns to guard its essence.
When essence and function merge as One,
responding to stimuli without end,
then one can govern without action—
thus, one’s body remains unharmed through life’s end.

**Scripture:** Seal its *mouth* (兑),
shut its *path*,
and one will never tire through life’s end.
Open its *mouth*,
complete its *affairs*,
and one will never be saved through life’s end.
Seeing what is small is called *clarity*,
guarding what is soft is called *strength*.
Using its *light*,
then returning to its *clarity*—
leaving no harm to one’s body,
this is called *following the constant*.

**Scripture:** The *mouth* is where desires take root.
The *path* is where actions arise.
With nature rectifying emotions,
the source of desires is sealed;
with principle governing affairs,
the path of actions is closed.
Thus, one can act without doing,
and do without acting—
so one never tires through life’s end.

Opening the source without sealing it,
one lengthens the desires of the emotions;
unblocking the path without closing it,
one completes the affairs of actions.
Thus, form and spirit both labor,
and one will never be saved through life’s end.

Knowing the art of sealing the *mouth* and closing the *path*,
this is called seeing the *minute* and *small*;
dulling the sharpness of desires,
dissolving the confusion of actions—
this is called guarding the *soft* and *weak*.
Guarding the *soft* and *weak*,
things cannot overpower one—
this is called *strength*.
Seeing the *minute* and *small*,
affairs cannot be muddled—
this is called *clarity*.
*Clarity* refers to inner vision (essence),
and *light* refers to outward radiance (function)."
